Tel.: +56 0412204324. Graphical abstract Enantioselective hydrogenation of 1-phenyl-1,2-propanodione (PPD) on Rh/MCM-41 catalysts was studied. The catalysts were prepared using Rh(acac)3 as a metal precursor and metal loadings that ranged from 0.5 to 1.5wt%. The samples were characterised by nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms at 77K using ICP-MS, XRD, TEM, XRD and XPS. The reaction was performed at 298K, and 0.01molL−1 of PPD and cinchonidine (CD) was used as chiral modifier. The effect of the modifier concentration on the enantioselectivity (ee) and the conversion level in the hydrogenation reaction shows a relationship between the activity and ee as well as the CD concentration. The volcano-type curve observed for each catalyst suggests competitive adsorption of the modifier and substrate on the catalyst surface. The metal loading influences both the Rh crystallite size and catalytic behaviour. An increase in the Rh levels was accompanied by a parallel increase in both the crystallite size and number of Rh ensembles with a subsequent enhancement in both the conversion level and ee. The catalyst with the highest metal loading was 1.0wt% Rh/MCM-41, and it displayed the highest ee among the catalysts studied. Additionally, the effects of hydrogen pressure and solvent nature on the catalytic activity were also studied. Moreover, the H2 pressure also influenced the conversion levels with only a minor effect on the ee values. Considering the solvent effects, we observed non-linear ee dependence with an increasing solvent dielectric constant, which showed a decrease in conversion levels in the order cyclohexane>toluene>tetrahydrofurane>dichloromethane. Keywords Rh catalysts Hydrogenation 1-phenyl-1,2-propanedione Enantioselectivity 1 Introduction Recently, asymmetric hydrogenation reactions over modified heterogeneous catalysts have been extensively studied. Complex mechanisms have been proposed for these reactions, which consider that adding a chiral template molecule is required for chiral induction during heterogeneous catalytic hydrogenation. The template molecule, which is CD herein, forms chirally modified sites through an interaction with a metal surface or, in the bulk liquid phase, through a substrate–modifier interaction [1–3]. In addition, the architecture of the catalyst surface influences the reaction to a certain extent. The solvent, hydrogen pressure and catalyst pre-treatment notably influence both the reaction rate and enantioselectivity [4–11]. Heterogeneous enantioselective hydrogenation of α-ketoesters has been intensively studied, whereas enantioselective hydrogenation of diones is less well-studied [12–15]. Enantiomerically pure hydroxyketones are used as intermediates for synthesising antifungals and chiral amino alcohols. Azole antifungals are interesting as drugs for AIDS-related diseases, and chiral amino alcohols (e.g., (1RS, 2SR)-(±)-2-amino-1-phenyl-1-propanol) are used as good vasoconstricting agents and nasal decongestants [16]. The most representative substrate is 1-phenyl-1,2-propanedione (PPD) in Scheme 1 , which is hydrogenated to (R or S)1-hydroxy-1-phenyl-2-propanone, and (R or S) 2-hydroxy-1-phenyl-1-propanone and has been used as a model compound for heterogeneous enantioselective hydrogenation by a few research groups [16]. In various enantioselective hydrogenation studies, Pt is used as the metal for carbonyl group reduction [8,10,17], whereas Pd is preferred for CC hydrogenation using cinchonidine as a chiral modifier [18–20]. Other transition metals, such as Ir, Rh or Ru, have been most studied in homogeneous phases [21,22]. These systems are generally chiral phosphine–metal complexes and represent an effective and highly studied area, but recovery and separation is a highly desirable goal. Recently, it was confirmed that Rh is an effective metal for heterogeneous enantioselective hydrogenation of certain prochiral compounds using nanoparticles stabilised with chiral ligands. Our group reported that chirally modified rhodium nanoparticles are effective for enantioselective hydrogenation [23,24]; however, the enantioselectivities appeared low or, at best, moderate for PPD hydrogenation. The main features of the chirally modified rhodium were compared with the corresponding reported platinum-CD systems. To improve the performance of heterogeneous Rh catalysts, we used the mesostructured MCM-41 system as a substrate for the catalytic component. This system may have potential applications for catalysis as an enantioselective catalyst for asymmetric hydrogenation. These enantioselective catalysts are essentially composed of a hexagonal arrangement of non-connected channels with a high porous structure, narrow pore distribution, high specific surface area and the appropriate pore diameter for processing large substrates. Certain authors have reported using Pt and Pd nanoparticles deposited on MCM-41 as enantioselective catalysts for asymmetric hydrogenation [25,26]. The better catalytic performance obtained using these catalysts was explained through the effect of the substrate mesostructure because the straight channels yield a confinement effect that leads to enhanced catalytic activity compared with other amorphous supported metal catalysts. The aim of the present work is to obtain and evaluate Rh catalysts supported on a mesostructured MCM-41 substrate to which a CD modifier and different metal loading were incorporated. In addition, the effects of the H2 pressure and solvent on catalytic performance were also studied using the most enantioselective catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals PPD, CD, cyclohexane, toluene, tetrahydrofurane (THF), dichloromethane, rhodium acetylacetonate (Rh(acac)3), aerosil silica (99.8%), tetramethylammonium hydroxide (TMAOH) and cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTMABr) were supplied by Aldrich, as received, and H2 (99.995%) was supplied by AGA. 2.2 Catalyst synthesis and characterisation The support MCM-41 was synthesised using the reaction of an aqueous solution of TMAOH and CTMABr with aerosil silica under continuous stirring. The resulting composition (molar ratio) of the homogeneous gel (pH=11) was SiO2:0.15 CTMABr:0.26 TMAOH:24.3 H2O and was dried as well as calcined for 1h in N2 followed by 10h under dynamic air flow at 810K. The catalysts were prepared through impregnation using a slight excess of Rh(acac)3 solution to fill the pore volume of the supports at the required levels to generate 0.5, 1.0 and 1.5wt.% of Rh. All catalysts were calcined under air at 573K and reduced in H2 at 773K for 1h prior to their characterisation or catalytic tests. The elemental content was quantitatively determined for the selected fresh catalysts through inductively coupled plasma spectrometry using a Perkin Elmer ICP-MS instrument after microwave-assisted digestion of the samples in a nitric/hydrochloric acid solution. The specific area and porosity were obtained from nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms at 77K performed in an automatic Micromeritics apparatus Model ASAP 2010 at a relative pressure in the range 0.05–0.995. The BET surface areas were calculated using a linear section of the BET plot based on IUPAC parameters. Pore-size distributions were calculated from the N2 adsorption branch using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda model (BJH). The powder X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded using Cu-Kα radiation (λ =1.542Å) and a Rigaku diffractometer equipped with a rotating anode operated at 45kV and 100mA. The counts were accumulated every 0.02° (2θ) at the scan speed 1° 2θ min−1. The interaction of hydrogen with the rhodium catalysts was studied in temperature-programmed reduction experiments (TPR), the catalysts were reduced under continuous flow using a 5% H2/Ar mixture (40cm3 min−1), at 10Kmin−1 from room temperature up to 873K in TPR/TPD2900 Micromeritics system. Hydrogen consumption was monitored with the aid of a TCD detector and recorded for TPR analysis. TEM micrographs were obtained in a Jeol Model JEM-1200 EXII System. The samples were loaded onto a holey carbon film that was supported on a copper grid by dipping the grid into a sample suspension in ethanol. The catalyst samples were prepared using the extractive replica procedure. Up to 300 individual metal particles were counted for each catalyst, and the surface area-weighted mean Rh diameter (d p) was calculated using the following equation: (1) d p = ∑ i n i d i 3 ∑ i n i d i 2 Where n i is the number of particles, and d i is the diameter. The size limit for detecting the Rh particles on the samples was ca. 1nm. The photoelectron spectra (XPS) were recorded using an Escalab 200R spectrometer with a hemispherical analyser operated using a constant pass energy mode and Mg Kα x-ray radiation (hν =1253.6eV) at 10mA and 12kV. The charge effects on the sample were corrected by fixing the binding energies (BE) for the Si2p core-level at 103.4eV. The surface Rh/Si ratios were estimated using the integrated intensities of Rh 3d and Si 2p lines after the background was subtracted and atomic sensitivity factors were used for normalisation [27]. 2.3 Activity tests The catalytic assays for PPD hydrogenation were performed in a stainless steel, Parr-type batch reactor. The substrate concentration was 0.01molL−1 in cyclohexane as the solvent. The samples were stirred at 700rpm under 20bar of H2 pressure. All further experiments were performed without external mass transfer limitations. The catalysts used were in the form of fine powders (>30μm), and a negligible effect from the pore diffusion limitations was assumed. In catalyst mass studies, the (PPD/Rh) molar ratio was varied, the PPD concentration was constant, and the catalyst mass was varied. An insignificant difference was obtained for the initial rates in the catalyst mass range studied (0.01–0.07g) because the reaction rate was proportional to the catalyst mass. These observations indicate that the gas–liquid and liquid–solid external mass transfer limitations were absent [6,28]. Liquid hydrogenation samples were periodically collected from the reactor and analysed using a gas chromatograph–mass spectrometer (GCMS-QP5050 Shimadzu) with a chiral β-dex 225 column (30m; Supelco) and electrolytic helium as carrier gas. The activity of the catalyst was followed by conversion levels: (2) X ( % ) = [ P P D ] 0 − [ P P D ] t ( m o l L − 1 ) [ P P D ] 0 ( m o l L − 1 ) ⋅ 100 where [PPD]0 corresponds to initial concentration of the PPD and [PPD]t as the concentration at different times. The turnover frequency (TOF) of the catalysts was calculated as follows. (3) T O F ( s − 1 ) = S u b s t r a t e h y d r o g e n a t e d ( m o l ) M e t a l l i c R h ( m o l ) ⋅ t i m e ( s ) The selectivity was measured by enantiomeric excess (ee) using the following equation: (4) e e C x ( % ) = [ R ] x − [ S ] x [ R ] x + [ S ] x ⋅ 100 % where [R] and [S] are the concentrations of the major and minor enantiomer, respectively. The regioselectivity (rs) was calculated as the ratio between (R)+(S)-1-hydroxy-1-phenylpropanone over (R)+(S)-2-hydroxy-1-phenylpropanone. (5) r s = R C 1 − S C 1 R C 2 + S C 2 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterisation The structure of MCM-41 was confirmed through an XRD analysis. Fig. 1 shows the XDR profiles of the samples studied. Diffraction lines corresponding with the planes (100), (110), (200), and (210) of a hexagonal structure with the symmetry P6 for the reflection planes (hkl) were observed. These data indicate the hollow and hexagonal form. The parameters of the cell (a o) for the MCM-41 hexagonal pore arrangement was 48Å, which is consistent with our previous reported results for the Pt/MCM-41 catalyst [25]. A structural characterisation of the solid MCM-41 is shown in Table 1 . Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms for the support are shown in Fig. 2 . These isotherms correspond to type IV (IUPAC classification) and display a H1-type hysteresis loop [29–31] associated with regular-form compact mesopores that present a narrow pore size distribution. The abrupt fall of the hysteresis loop indicates that the pores have a uniform and cylindrical shape. The surface areas determined by the BET equation show that, upon Rh loading, the textural properties only change slightly, indicating that Rh incorporation does not significantly affect the original structure, which is consistent with the XRD results. In addition, mesostructured catalysts have framework pore sizes in the range 3–5nm, which are sufficiently large to accommodate the starting reagent and reaction products. Crocker et al. [32] reported that the critical dimension of phenyl acetylene is essentially determined by the benzene ring thickness (similar to PPD) and adopts the value 0.3nm. Therefore, we inferred that the apparent substrate size dependence arises from the reactant chemisorption spatial requirements, both on the external surface sites and in the restricted internal region. Three different catalysts were used for this study on the metal loading effect. Table 2 shows the ICP analyses and reveals that the catalysts’ metal content is similar to the nominal content, which indicates that all of the metal was deposited during synthesis of the catalysts. Fig. 3 shows the TPR profiles for the calcined Rh/MCM-41 samples. Two reduction peaks are shown. One peak is at lower temperatures and centred at 353K, which shows a similar intensity in all samples and can be associated with reduction of rhodium oxide particles located on the external mesopore channels. A second peak is located at higher temperatures (ca. 573K), which can be due to reduction of rhodium oxide crystallites, which are located inside the mesopores and interact with the substrate. These observations are consistent with a previous report, which argued that reduction/oxidation of particles located inside the mesopores of the substrate always requires the most severe reduction conditions [25]. The intensities of these second reduction peak increase with greater rhodium loading. The quantity of H2 consumed indicates that level of hydrogen reduced is close to the stoichiometric values for the samples with higher Rh loading. For the catalyst containing 0.5 wt% Rh, the level of reduction was approximately 85%. Fig. 4 shows certain representative TEM micrographs and the metal particle size distribution for the Rh/MCM-41 catalysts studied. A narrow particle size distribution is shown, and the average value of the metal particle sizes obtained using TEM are summarised in Table 2. As expected, a slight increase in the particle size upon increasing Rh loading is shown. Most of the crystallite sizes were in the range 2.0–4.0nm. Fig. 5 shows the Rh 3d5/2 core level spectra for the catalysts studied. The binding energies for Rh0, Rh+ and Rh3+ are 307.1eV, 307.6–309.6eV and 308.8–311.3eV, respectively [33], as shown Table 3 . All Rh3d core-level profiles showed two doublets, the major Rh3d5/2 peaks for which appeared at approximately 307.2 and 309.1eV. These observations support the notion that the Rh component in these catalysts exists in two different chemical environments: BE at ca. 307.1eV, which is associated with metallic Rh0, and the BE at 39.1eV, which originated from the oxidised Rhδ+ species. These values may be explained by considering that the binding energy is affected not only by an electronic interaction between the metal and other catalyst components but also by the small particle size of the metal nanoparticles, as we have reported for other MCM-41 catalytic systems [25,26]. It has also been shown that the concentration of Rhδ+ species decreases with greater metal loading on the support surface. Considering the metal particle sizes obtained using TEM, as shown in Table 2, only a few changes in the BE should be expected for the 1.0% Rh and 1.5% Rh catalysts. Additionally, the Rh/Si atomic surface ratios obtained through XPS showed comparable values for both samples, which is consistent with the TEM results. 3.2 PPD hydrogenation Preliminary experiments using small catalyst particle sizes (<200μm) and a high stirring speed (800rpm) precluded the absence of external and internal mass transfer limitations. In previous studies, we demonstrated that this reaction is a structure-sensitive reaction. In fact, the ability of the support surface to disperse the metal restricts the metal particle size and affects the activity and enantioselectivity; however, the average metal particle size can be modified by changing the metal loading. 3.2.1 1.0% Rh/MCM-41: modifier concentration To improve enantioselectivity for a given system, a study on the effect of the modifier concentration is relevant. Margitfalvi et al. [34–38] reported that the modifier concentration dependence forms a bell-type curve during ethyl pyruvate hydrogenation. Similar results have been published by Toukoniitty et al. [9,39]. Fig. 6 displays the change in conversion level. In all cases, pseudo-first-order kinetics with respect to PPD were observed. The reaction rate maximises as the modifier concentration increased (Table 4 ). The main product was 1-hydroxy-1-phenyl-2-propanone (1R- and 1S-PP), and the regioisomer 2-hydroxy-1-phenyl-1-propanone (2R- and 2S-PP) was formed in minor quantities at the CD concentration>5.0×10−4 molL−1. The regioselectivity is approximately 43%, as shown in Table 4. This behaviour is likely due to higher steric hindrance from the spherical methyl group compared with the flat phenyl ring. The hydrogenation rates of hydroxyketones to diols were not reported because these reactions did not occur under the conditions herein. The maximum enantioselectivity was observed at moderate modifier concentrations (0.5mmolL−1) than the maximum hydrogenation rate, as shown in Fig. 7 . However, it should be emphasised that the maximum appears relatively close to the 2:1 molar ratio of modifier to surface Rh and away from the 0.05:1 ratio of modifier to reactant in the bulk liquid. The enantiomeric excess of 1R-PP was approximately 54%, and it was almost constant with increasing PPD conversion. These results indicate that the modifier not only induces chirality but also enhances the activity, which is consistent with Margitfalvi et al. [36,38] for ethyl pyruvate hydrogenation and our previous work on PPD hydrogenation using Pt/MCM-41 catalysts [25]. At a lower CD concentration, only a small fraction of the metallic phase is covered by the modifier, and the remaining metal sites are mainly occupied by the substrate and dissociated hydrogen. The adsorbed modifier interacts with a PPD molecule and forms an adsorbed supramolecule, which is hydrogenated by hydrogen spillover to produce the R-enantiomer. Additionally, the adsorbed substrate may also be hydrogenated, which yields the racemic mixture, and, therefore, may produce low enantioselectivity. Conversely, at a higher CD concentration, dimer formation (CD)2 limits the quantity of the desired enantiomer. The Rh nanoparticles with (CD)2 adsorbed on their surface cannot accept parallel adsorption of the PPD phenyl group that controls the ee and rs. In addition, the conversion levels can be decreased through active blockage. 3.2.2 Metal loading The influence of Rh loading on enantioselective hydrogenation was determined using a series of Rh/MCM-41 catalysts for which the nominal Rh levels were 0.5, 1.0, and 1.5% Rh. As demonstrated through certain exploratory experiments, the CD concentration is an important parameter in the target reaction; hence, it was investigated. Thus, the experiments were conducted under standard conditions using PPD at 0.01molL−1. The characterisation results are shown in Table 2 with the Rh concentrations determined using ICP-MS, the Rh dispersion determined using TEM and the calculated Rh average particle size. The PPD hydrogenation rates and ee values are lower than reported for the α-ketoesters [40]. This observation can be attributed to the greater ability of diketones to form oligomers and polymers, which are considered strong catalyst poisons. The 1.5% Rh/MCM-41 catalyst was the most active and yielded conversion levels up to 80%. This value is promising compared with the best value obtained for asymmetric hydrogenation of PPD using 5% Rh/Al2O3 [10]. Fig. 8 shows the ee vs CD concentration for the Rh/MCM-41 catalysts. The ee is a clearly a function of both the Rh loading and CD concentration. The best ee results (65–70%) were obtained with the 1.0% Rh/MCM-41 catalyst. The smooth variation of the ee maximum as a function of Rh dispersion suggests that Rh particle size is an important and central parameter that controls enantioselectivity. If the Rh loading is too low, the particle sizes are also smaller and ineffective at interacting with the alkaloid modifier results. Conversely, a slightly increase in Rh loading produces large nanoparticles and lower overall reactivity (Table 2), but the selectivity is enhanced because, at a lower CD concentration, the Rh sites can be effectively modified. In our case, the differences in conversion levels and ee demonstrated by the 1.0% Rh/MCM-41 catalyst compared to its 1.5% Rh/MCM-41 homologue can be explained based on the mesostructure silica effect. The straight channel observed in this type of support produces a confinement effect, which enhances the catalytic activity, but the Rh nanoparticles sizes differ. For 1.5% Rh/MCM-41, the mean size is 3.7nm, which is similar to the MCM-41 pore diameter (Table 1); under these conditions, the catalyst shows diffusional resistance attributed to pore blockage by the active phase, which is consistent with previous studies reported by Murzin et al. [26]. This behaviour can also be due to high metal loading, which blocks the catalyst pores and, hence, limits reactant diffusion into the pore structure. In this work, the metal Rh particles ca. 3.2nm in size developed on the 1.0% Rh/MCM-41 catalyst appeared optimal. However, further work is required to fully ascertain the optimal Rh particle size. This observation is similar to the relationship observed for ethyl pyruvate hydrogenation over Rh/Al2O3 catalysts with particle size distributions where in the maxima were at 1.5nm and 2.0nm. The smaller particle size yielded poor enantioselection, and it was concluded that such small particles could not interact effectively with the modifier and the reactant [40]. 3.2.3 The effect of hydrogen pressure The effect of hydrogen pressure was negligible where the hydrogen pressure was varied from 10 to 40bar. Fig. 9 shows the TOF and selectivity as a function of H2 pressure. The surface H2 concentration may directly influence the reactant adsorption and, thus, enantioselectivity. An increase in H2 pressure (from 10 to 40bar) markedly effects the TOF but only slightly effects the ee. The TOF increases with increasing pressure. The reaction proceeded slowly at 10bar; the PPD conversion was only 47% after 240min. However, at 40bar, the PPD conversion was 89% over the same time period, which indicates that hydrogen adsorption is mainly non-competitive. The role of hydrogen adsorption in the hydrogenation process is interesting. On one hand, hydrogen is dissociatively adsorbed on Rh and competes with organic molecules for metal sites; on the other hand, hydrogen molecules are much smaller than the organic molecules. Previous work has shown that PPD hydrogenation on a commercial Pt/Al2O3 catalyst proceeds with a quasi-zero reaction order with respect to hydrogen over a minor pressure range (1–5bar) [4,6,10]. The approximately linear plot of TOF values versus hydrogen pressure indicates first-order kinetics with respect to hydrogen pressure. At pressures >20bar, other hydrogenation products were detected. At the CD concentration used, the PPD phenyl ring was not hydrogenated to a cyclohexyl ring; thus, undesirable products were formed both from the reactant and each product, which yielded seven hydroxyl products. It can be concluded that CO non-selective hydrogenation is generally more favourable at higher pressures due to the short residence time of PPD in the straight channels. 3.2.4 Solvent effects In heterogeneous asymmetric hydrogenation, enantioselectivity is sensitive to the solvent used, such as for asymmetric hydrogenation of PPD catalysed by Pt/CD [11,41]. Solvents with dielectric constants ranging from 2 to 8 were included in this study for PPD hydrogenation over a 1.0% Rh/MCM-41 catalyst; these values correspond to pure solvents, excluding the effects from low levels of reactants and modifiers (CD/PPD 0.05). We used weakly polar solvents because CD is highly soluble therein. The results are shown in Fig. 10 and correspond to a qualitative model, including the enantioselectivity and dielectric constant of the pure solvents, similar to the proposal in Toukoniitty et al. [11,41]. These results show that TOF decreases with an increase in solvent polarity. The highest conversion was observed for cyclohexane, and low reaction rates were observed for tetrahydrofuran (THF). The side products 2R- or 2S-PP and diols were not detected. The solvent is an essential factor because it modulates the modifier conformation, modifier–reactant interaction and solution hydrogen concentration, among other features, and it affects the enantioselectivity [11,42–44]. Solvent effects over Rh are similar to Pt catalysts (e.g., the highest and dichloromethane the lowest eeC1 are observed in cyclohexane). Toukoniitty et al. [11] reported that the initial hydrogenation rate did not correlate with hydrogen solubility. Our results for PPD hydrogenation with the 1.0% Rh/MCM-41 catalyst show a roughly linear correlation between the solvent dielectric constant and optical yield as well as reaction rate. The highest ee was recorded using hydrocarbon solvents with the dielectric constant <2.3, which is qualitatively consistent with findings by Baiker and coworkers [45] for ethyl pyruvate hydrogenation, showing that optical yield decreased when solvent polarity increases. However, exceptions have been demonstrated (e.g., the study by Toukoniitty et al. [10] on PPD hydrogenation using commercial Rh/Al2O3 catalysts, which showed similar conversion levels for toluene (ɛ: 2.34) and acetic acid (ɛ: 6.2)). We show that apolar–aprotic solvents positively influence both selectivity and activity because these solvents not only improve the reactants’ mobility but also enhance an effective interaction between a CD-PPD complex or Rh-CD-PPD supramolecular complex, as reported Toukoniitty et al. [11]. 4 Conclusions Cinchonidine-modified Rh/MCM-41 catalysts with different Rh loading ratios are effective for enantioselective PPD hydrogenation. Here, we applied a mesostructured support to prepare a series of Rh catalysts with 0.5–1.5wt% Rh. This support provided small Rh particles with relatively narrow particle size distributions, and the best catalyst (1.0wt% Rh) showed outstanding enantioselectivity for PPD hydrogenation. The Rh dispersion and, hence, Rh particle size appear to be the dominant factor in combination with the appropriate CD concentration for the reaction. These three Rh loading levels display volcano-type curves for the cinchonidine concentration studies, which showed an optimum quantity of modifier required for the maximum enantioselectivity using each catalyst. This behaviour can be attributed to nanoparticle and dispersion differences. More importantly, the activity and selectivity were improved using a mesostructured support. It is suggested that the significant difference in the support structure improves the interaction efficiency between the Rh metal surface and modifier–substrate adduct adsorption through the confinement effect. An increase in the H2 pressures accelerates the hydrogenation rates, but decreases the selectivity to CO in the adjacent phenyl group. Finally, the solvent effect yields a linear correlation between the solvent dielectric constant-hydrogenation rate and non-linear correlation; ee displayed the highest enantioselectivity when cyclohexane was used as the solvent. coredata.dc:description: Enantioselective hydrogenation of 1-phenyl-1,2-propanodione (PPD) on Rh/MCM-41 catalysts was studied. The catalysts were prepared using Rh(acac)3 as a metal precursor and metal loadings that ranged from 0.5 to 1.5wt%. The samples were characterised by nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms at 77K using ICP-MS, XRD, TEM, XRD and XPS. The reaction was performed at 298K, and 0.01molL−1 of PPD and cinchonidine (CD) was used as chiral modifier. The effect of the modifier concentration on the enantioselectivity (ee) and the conversion level in the hydrogenation reaction shows a relationship between the activity and ee as well as the CD concentration. The volcano-type curve observed for each catalyst suggests competitive adsorption of the modifier and substrate on the catalyst surface. The metal loading influences both the Rh crystallite size and catalytic behaviour. An increase in the Rh levels was accompanied by a parallel increase in both the crystallite size and number of Rh ensembles with a subsequent enhancement in both the conversion level and ee. The catalyst with the highest metal loading was 1.0wt% Rh/MCM-41, and it displayed the highest ee among the catalysts studied. Additionally, the effects of hydrogen pressure and solvent nature on the catalytic activity were also studied. Moreover, the H2 pressure also influenced the conversion levels with only a minor effect on the ee values. Considering the solvent effects, we observed non-linear ee dependence with an increasing solvent dielectric constant, which showed a decrease in conversion levels in the order cyclohexane>toluene>tetrahydrofurane>dichloromethane.
coredata.dc:title: Enantioselective hydrogenation of 1-phenyl-1,2-propanodione on cinchonidine-modified Rh/MCM-41 catalysts
